form.preferredDefinition: This protocol provides instructions for drawing, processing and storing blood according to the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) methods. Because there are many comparable assays for measuring aspartate aminotransferase (AST), the protocol also provides basic guidelines to aid comparability among different studies.

headerInstruction.text: The following is a summary version of the full National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey 20112012 protocol.Exclusion Criteria:Persons will be excluded from this component if they: Report that they have hemophilia or Report that they ha..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: Do you have hemophilia? (aspartate_aminotransferase_have_hemophilia)
If the SP answers "Yes," the SP is excluded from the blood draw. If SP answers "No" or "Don't Know," blood is drawn from the SP (hemo_811201)
Have you received cancer chemotherapy in the past four weeks or do you anticipate such therapy in the next four weeks? (aspartate_aminotransferase_chemotheraphy_4weeks)
If the SP answers "Yes," the SP is excluded from the blood draw. If SP answers "No" or "Don't Know," blood is drawn from the SP (chemo_811201)
Age (aspartate_aminotransferase_age)
Red blood cell aspartate aminotransferase level (aspartate_aminotransferase_amount)
Repeatability of the red blood cell aspartate aminotransferase assay (aspartate_aminotransferase_assay_repeatability)
Record the results of the blood draw. (aspartate_aminotransferase_blood_draw_results)
Record reasons for a tube not being drawn according to the protocol. (aspartate_aminotransferase_blood_draw_tube_deviation)
Coefficients of variation of the red blood cell aspartate aminotransferase assay (aspartate_aminotransferase_coefficients_variation_assay)
Make of the equipment used to perform the red blood cell aspartate aminotransferase assay (aspartate_aminotransferase_equipment_make)
Manufacturer of the equipment used to perform the red blood cell aspartate aminotransferase assay (aspartate_aminotransferase_equipment_manufacturer)
If serum is hemolyzed, turbid, lipemic, or iteric, then describe. (aspartate_aminotransferase_serum_description)
Determine if the serum is hemolyzed, turbid, lipemic, or icteric. (aspartate_aminotransferase_serum_determination)
Record any comments about the venipuncture. (aspartate_aminotransferase_venipuncture_comments)

Venipuncture Procedures: Editor's Note: Please review chapter 4 of the Laboratory Procedures Manual from the 20112012 National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) for a full description of phlebotomy procedures. This manual is posted here, and is also available at the NHANES website: 20112012 NHANES Laboratory Procedures ManualVenipuncture should generally be performed using the median cubital, cephalic, or basilic veins in the left arm unless this arm is unsuitable. If the veins in the left arm are unsuitable, look for suitable veins on the right arm. If the veins in the antecubital space on both arms are not suitable, then look for veins in the forearm or dorsal side of the hand on the left arm/hand and then the right arm/hand. Recording the Results of the Venipuncture Procedure: Immediately after completing the venipuncture, record the results of the blood draw, the reasons for a tube not being drawn according to the protocol, and any comments about the venipuncture. (venipuncture_811201)

Blood Processing: Please review chapter 8 of the Laboratory Procedures Manual from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey 20112012 for a full description of blood processing procedures: 20112012 NHANES Laboratory Procedures Manual. Allow the blood to clot by setting aside for 30 to 45 minutes at room temperature. Do not clot for more than an hour. Centrifuge the tube at room temperature to separate the serum and aliquot into an appropriate storage tube. Determine if the serum is hemolyzed, turbid, lipemic, or icteric. If so, enter a comment to describe the serum. (processing_811201)

Laboratory Assay for Aspartate Aminotransferase (AST): The Sickle Cell Disease Cardiovascular, Pulmonary, and Renal Working Group notes that there are a number of different assays and instruments that are appropriate to measure the concentration of aspartate aminotransferase (AST). Once an assay is chosen for a particular study, the Working Group recommends that no changes in the protocol be made over the course of the study. To aid comparability, the Working Group recommends that the investigator record the make and manufacturer of equipment used and the repeatability and coefficients of variation for the assay. (lab_assay_811201)
Reference Ranges for Aspartate Aminotransferase (AST): Age (years) IU/L06 1863610 21441020 1338 greater than 20 1333 (ranges_811201)

protocol.preferredDefinition: This protocol provides instructions for drawing, processing and storing blood according to the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) methods. Because there are many comparable assays for measuring aspartate aminotransferase (AST), the protocol also provides basic guidelines to aid comparability among different studies.

form.longName: PhenX PX820102 - Quality Of Care Children
form.preferredDefinition: The Consumer Assessment of Healthcare Providers and Systems (CAHPS®) Health Plan Survey 4.0 Child Medicaid Questionnaire includes general questions about access to care and quality of care and additional questions about the services provided to children with chronic conditions. Items CC1-CC38 of the questionnaire are version 4.0 of the Children with Chronic Conditions Item Set.

headerInstruction.text: The Consumer Assessment of Healthcare Providers and Systems (CAHPS®) Health Plan Survey 4.0 Child Medicaid QuestionnaireSurvey Instructions: Answer each question by selecting the best answer to the right of the question. You are sometimes t..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: 1. Our records show that your child is now in {INSERT HEALTH PLAN NAME}. Is that right? (qualityofcarechildren_recorded_health_plan_name)
2. What is the name of your child's health plan? (qualityofcarechildren_current_reported_health_plan_name)

Your Child's Health Care in the Last 6 Months: These questions ask about your child's health care. Do not include care your child got when he or she stayed overnight in a hospital. Do not include the times your child went for dental care visits. (months_820102)

3. In the last 6 months, did your child have an illness, injury, or condition that needed care right away in a clinic, emergency room, or doctor's office? (qualityofcarechildren_needed_immediate_care_last6months)

4. In the last 6 months, when your child needed care right away, how often did your child get care as soon as you thought he or she needed? (qualityofcarechildren_think_received_immediate_care_last6months)

5. In the last 6 months, not counting the times your child needed care right away, did you make any appointments for your child's health care at a doctor's office or clinic? (qualityofcarechildren_appointment_office_clinic_last6months)

6. In the last 6 months, not counting the times your child needed care right away, how often did you get an appointment for health care at a doctor's office or clinic as soon as you thought your child needed? (qualityofcarechildren_received_appointment_office_clinic_last6months)

7. In the last 6 months, not counting the times your child went to an emergency room, how many times did he or she go to a doctor's office or clinic to get health care? (qualityofcarechildren_received_health_care_last6months)

validValue.meaningText: None ? If None, go to #9 [If items CC5-CC7 or CC5-CC18 are included: go to #CC5; if only items CC8-CC18 are included: go to #CC8]
validValue.description: None ? If None, go to #9 [If items CC5-CC7 or CC5-CC18 are included: go to #CC5; if only items CC8-CC18 are included: go to #CC8]

question.questionText: CC1. In the last 6 months, how often did you have your questions answered by your child's doctors or other health providers? (qualityofcarechildrendoctor_provider_answered_questions_last6months)

CC2. Choices for your child's treatment or health care can include choices about medicine, surgery, or other treatment. In the last 6 months, did your child's doctor or other health provider tell you there was more than one choice for your child's treatment or health care? (qualityofcarechildren_treatment_care_choice_last6months)

CC3. In the last 6 months, did your child's doctor or other health provider talk with you about the pros and cons of each choice for your child's treatment or health care? (qualityofcarechildren_pros_cons_treatment_care_choice_last6months)

CC4. In the last 6 months, when there was more than one choice for your child's treatment or health care, did your child's doctor or other health provider ask you which choice was best for your child? (qualityofcarechildren_best_for_child_treatment_care_choice_last6months)

8. Using any number from 0 to 10, where 0 is the worst health care possible and 10 is the best health care possible, what number would you use to rate all your child's health care in the last 6 months? (qualityofcarechildren_rate_health_care_last6months)
CC5. Is your child now enrolled in any kind of school or daycare? (qualityofcarechildren_enrolled_school_daycare)

validValue.meaningText: No ? If No, go to #9 [If items CC8-CC18 are included: go to #CC8]
validValue.description: No ? If No, go to #9 [If items CC8-CC18 are included: go to #CC8]

question.questionText: CC6. In the last 6 months, did you need your child's doctors or other health providers to contact a school or daycare center about your child's health or health care? (qualityofcarechildrendoctor_healthprovider_contact_school_daycare_last6months)

validValue.meaningText: No ? If No, go to #9 [If items CC8-CC18 are included: go to #CC8]
validValue.description: No ? If No, go to #9 [If items CC8-CC18 are included: go to #CC8]

question.questionText: CC7. In the last 6 months, did you get the help you needed from your child's doctors or other health providers in contacting your child's school or daycare? (qualityofcarechildrendoctor_healthprovider_help_school_daycare_last6months)
Option: Insert additional questions about general health care here. Specialized Services. (option_820102)

CC8. Special medical equipment or devices include a walker, wheelchair, nebulizer, feeding tubes, or oxygen equipment. In the last 6 months, did you get or try to get any special medical equipment or devices for your child? (qualityofcarechildren_specialmedicalequipment_devices_last6months)
CC9. In the last 6 months, how often was it easy to get special medical equipment or devices for your child? (qualityofcarechildren_easy_getspecialmedicalequipment_devices_last6months)

CC10. Did anyone from your child's health plan, doctor's office, or clinic help you get special medical equipment or devices for your child? (qualityofcarechildren_help_getspecialmedicalequipment_devices)
CC11. Does your child need or get special therapy such as physical, occupational, or speech therapy? (qualityofcarechildren_need_getspecial_therapy)
CC12. In the last 6 months, how often was it easy to get this therapy for your child? (qualityofcarechildren_easy_getspecial_therapy_last6months)
CC13. Did anyone from your child's health plan, doctor's office, or clinic help you get this therapy for your child? (qualityofcarechildren_help_getspecial_therapy)

CC14. In the last 6 months, did you get or try to get treatment or counseling for your child for an emotional, developmental, or behavioral problem? (qualityofcarechildren_treatment_counseling_last6months)
CC15. In the last 6 months, how often was it easy to get this treatment or counseling for your child? (qualityofcarechildren_easy_gettreatment_counseling_last6months)
CC16. Did anyone from your child's health plan, doctor's office, or clinic help you get this treatment or counseling for your child? (qualityofcarechildren_help_gettreatment_counseling)

CC17. In the last 6 months, did your child get care from more than one kind of health care provider or use more than one kind of health care service? (qualityofcarechildren_morethanone_provider_service_last6months)

CC18. In the last 6 months, did anyone from your child's health plan, doctor's office, or clinic help coordinate your child's care among these different providers or services? (qualityofcarechildren_helpcoordinate_differentprovidersservices_last6months)
Your Child's Personal Doctor (personal_dr_820102)
9. A personal doctor is the one your child would see if he or she needs a checkup or gets sick or hurt. Does your child have a personal doctor? (qualityofcarechildren_have_personaldoctor)
10. In the last 6 months, how many times did your child visit his or her personal doctor for care? (qualityofcarechildren_visit_personaldoctor_last6months)
11. In the last 6 months, how often did your child's personal doctor explain things in a way that was easy to understand? (qualityofcarechildren_personaldoctor_explain_understand_last6months)
12. In the last 6 months, how often did your child's personal doctor listen carefully to you? (qualityofcarechildren_personaldoctor_listen_carefully_last6months)
13. In the last 6 months, how often did your child's personal doctor show respect for what you had to say? (qualityofcarechildren_personaldoctor_show_respect_last6months)
14. Is your child able to talk with doctors about his or her health care? (qualityofcarechildren_child_talk_health_care)

15. In the last 6 months, how often did your child's personal doctor explain things in a way that was easy for your child to understand? (qualityofcarechildren_personaldoctor_explainchild_understand_last6months)
16. In the last 6 months, how often did your child's personal doctor spend enough time with your child? (qualityofcarechildren_personaldoctor_timewith_child_last6months)
17. In the last 6 months, did your child's personal doctor talk with you about how your child is feeling, growing, or behaving? (qualityofcarechildren_personaldoctor_talkwith_you_last6months)

18. Using any number from 0 to 10, where 0 is the worst personal doctor possible and 10 is the best personal doctor possible, what number would you use to rate your child's personal doctor? (qualityofcarechildren_rate_personaldoctor)
CC19. Does your child have any medical, behavioral, or other health conditions that have lasted for more than 3 months? (qualityofcarechildren_medical_behavioralhealthconditions_morethan_3months)

CC20. Does your child's personal doctor understand how these medical, behavioral, or other health conditions affect your child's daytoday life? (qualityofcarechildren_personaldoctor_understandaffectchild_dailylife)

CC21. Does your child's personal doctor understand how your child's medical, behavioral, or other health conditions affect your FAMILY'S daytoday life? (qualityofcarechildren_personaldoctor_understandaffectfamily_dailylife)
Option: Insert additional questions about personal doctor here. Getting Health Care From a Specialist. (specialist_820102)

19. Specialists are doctors like surgeons, heart doctors, allergy doctors, skin doctors, and other doctors who specialize in one area of health care. In the last 6 months, did you try to make any appointments for your child to see a specialist? (qualityofcarechildren_appointment_specialists_last6months)
20. In the last 6 months, how often was it easy to get appointments for your child with specialists? (qualityofcarechildren_appointment_specialists_easy_getlast6months)
21. How many specialists has your child seen in the last 6 months? (qualityofcarechildren_specialistsseen_last6months)

22. We want to know your rating of the specialist your child saw most often in the last 6 months. Using any number from 0 to 10, where 0 is the worst specialist possible and 10 is the best specialist possible, what number would you use to rate that specialist? (qualityofcarechildren_rate_specialistseen_last6months)
Option: Insert additional questions about specialist care here. Your Child's Health Plan. (health_plan_820102)
23. In the last 6 months, did you try to get any kind of care, tests, or treatment for your child through his or her health plan? (qualityofcarechildren_caretests_treatment_healthplan_last6months)

24. In the last 6 months, how often was it easy to get the care, tests, or treatment you thought your child needed through his or her health plan? (qualityofcarechildren_easygetcare_tests_treatmenthealthplan_last6months)
25. In the last 6 months, did you try to get information or help from customer service at your child's health plan? (qualityofcarechildren_information_help_healthplan_last6months)
26. In the last 6 months, how often did customer service at your child's health plan give you the information or help you needed? (qualityofcarechildren_customerservice_give_healthplan_last6months)

27. In the last 6 months, how often did customer service staff at your child's health plan treat you with courtesy and respect? (qualityofcarechildren_customerservice_courtesyrespect_healthplan_last6months)
28. In the last 6 months, did your child's health plan give you any forms to fill out? (qualityofcarechildren_healthplan_forms_last6months)
29. In the last 6 months, how often were the forms from your child's health plan easy to fill out? (qualityofcarechildren_healthplan_forms_easyfill_last6months)

30. Using any number from 0 to 10, where 0 is the worst health plan possible and 10 is the best health plan possible, what number would you use to rate your child's health plan? (qualityofcarechildren_rate_health_plan)
Option: Insert additional questions about the health plan here. Prescription Medicines. (prescripts_820102)
CC22. In the last 6 months, did you get or refill any prescription medicines for your child? (qualityofcarechildren_prescription_medicines_last6months)
CC23. In the last 6 months, how often was it easy to get prescription medicines for your child through his or her health plan? (qualityofcarechildren_easy_getprescription_medicines_last6months)
CC24. Did anyone from your child's health plan, doctor's office, or clinic help you get your child's prescription medicines? (qualityofcarechildren_help_getprescription_medicines)
About Your Child and You (you_child_820102)
31. In general, how would you rate your child's overall health? (qualityofcarechildren_rate_overall_health)
CC25. Does your child currently need or use medicine prescribed by a doctor (other than vitamins)? (qualityofcarechildren_use_prescribedmedicine)
CC26. Is this because of any medical, behavioral, or other health condition? (qualityofcarechildren_specialtherapy_medical_behavioral_health)
CC27. Is this a condition that has lasted or is expected to last for at least 12 months? (qualityofcarechildren_condition_last_expected_12months)

CC28. Does your child need or use more medical care, more mental health services, or more educational services than is usual for most children of the same age? (qualityofcarechildren_needusemore_medicalmentalhealth_educational)
CC29. Is this because of any medical, behavioral, or other health condition? (qualityofcarechildren_limited_preventedmedicalbehavioral_otherhealth)
CC30. Is this a condition that has lasted or is expected to last for at least 12 months? (qualityofcarechildren_condition_lastexpected_atleast_12months)
CC31. Is your child limited or prevented in any way in his or her ability to do the things most children of the same age can do? (qualityofcarechildren_limited_preventedability)
CC32. Is this because of any medical, behavioral, or other health condition? (qualityofcarechildren_needusemore_becausemedicalbehavioral_other_health)
CC33. Is this a condition that has lasted or is expected to last for at least 12 months? (qualityofcarechildren_limited_preventedcondition_lastexpected_12months)
CC34. Does your child need or get special therapy such as physical, occupational, or speech therapy? (cc34_820201)
CC35. Is this because of any medical, behavioral, or other health condition? (qualityofcarechildren_use_prescribedmedicine_medicalbehavioral_health)
CC36. Is this a condition that has lasted or is expected to last for at least 12 months? (qualityofcarechildren_specialtherapy_condition_lastexpected_12months)

CC37. Does your child have any kind of emotional, developmental, or behavioral problem for which he or she needs or gets treatment or counseling? (qualityofcarechildren_have_emotionaldevelopmental_behavioraltreatment_counseling)
CC38. Has this problem lasted or is it expected to last for at least 12 months? (qualityofcarechildren_problem_last_expected_12months)
32. What is your child's age? (qualityofcarechildren_child_age)
32a. What is your child's age? Write in (qualityofcarechildren_child_ageother)
33. Is your child male or female? (qualityofcarechildren_child_gender)
34. Is your child of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent? (qualityofcarechildren_child_origin_descent)
35. What is your child's race? Please mark one or more. (qualityofcarechildren_child_race)

validValue.meaningText: Native Hawiian or other Pacific Islander
validValue.description: Native Hawiian or other Pacific Islander

question.questionText: 36. What is your age? (qualityofcarechildren_your_age)
37. Are you male or female? (qualityofcarechildren_your_gender)
38. What is the highest grade or level of school that you have completed? (qualityofcarechildren_your_highest_gradelevel_completed)

validValue.meaningText: Some high school, but did not graduate
validValue.description: Some high school, but did not graduate

question.questionText: 39. How are you related to the child? (qualityofcarechildren_related_to_child)
40. Did someone help you complete this survey? (qualityofcarechildren_help_complete_survey)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Consumer Assessment of Healthcare Providers and Systems (CAHPS®) Health Plan Survey 4.0 Child Medicaid Questionnaire includes general questions about access to care and quality of care and additional questions about the services provided to children with chronic conditions. Items CC1-CC38 of the questionnaire are version 4.0 of the Children with Chronic Conditions Item Set.

form.longName: PhenX PX820201 - Adult Sickle Cell Quality Of Life Measurement Informatio
form.preferredDefinition: This protocol includes 30 self-administered questions from the short form of the Adult Sickle Cell Quality of Life Measurement Information System (ASCQ-Me). Domains covered include emotional impact (5 items), social functioning impact (5 items), sleep impact (5 items), stiffness impact (5 items), pain episode (5 items), and pain frequency (5 items).

headerInstruction.text: Adult Sickle Cell Quality of Life Measurement Information System (ASCQMe): Answer all the questions by checking the box to the left of your answer. Emotional Impact.

module.longName: Adult Sickle Cell Quality of Life Measurement Information System (ASCQ-Me)
module.preferredDefinition: Adult Sickle Cell Quality of Life Measurement Information System (ASCQ-Me)

question.questionText: 1. In the past 7 days, how often did you feel completely hopeless because of your health? (qualityoflife_scdadult_completely_hopeless_past7days)
2. In the past 7 days, how lonely did you feel because of your health problems? (qualityoflife_scdadult_lonely_past7days)
3. In the past 7 days, how depressed were you about your health problems? (qualityoflife_scdadult_depressed_past7days)
4. In the past 7 days, how much did you worry about getting sick? (qualityoflife_scdadult_worry_past7days)
5. In the past 7 days, how often were you very worried about needing to go to the hospital? (qualityoflife_scdadult_often_worried_past7days)
Social Functioning Impact (social_820201)
1. In the past 30 days, how much did you rely on others to take care of you because of your health? (qualityoflife_scdadult_relyon_others_past30days)
2. In the past 30 days, how often did your health slow you down? (qualityoflife_scdadult_often_slowdown_past30days)
3. In the past 30 days, how often did your health make it hard for you to do things? (qualityoflife_scdadult_oftenhard_dothings_past30days)
4. In the past 30 days, how often did your health keep you from going out? (qualityoflife_scdadult_oftenprevent_going_past30days)
5. In the past 30 days, how much did your health make it hard for you to do things with your friends? (qualityoflife_scdadult_howmuch_dothings_past30days)
Sleep Impact (sleep_820201)
1. In the past 7 days, how often did you stay up most of the night because you could not fall asleep? (qualityoflife_scdadult_oftenunable_sleep_past7days)
2. In the past 7 days, how often was it very easy for you to fall asleep? (qualityoflife_scdadult_ofteneasy_sleep_past7days)
3. In the past 7 days, how often did you have a lot of trouble falling asleep? (qualityoflife_scdadult_trouble_sleep_past7days)
4. In the past 7 days, how often did you stay up all night because you could not fall asleep? (qualityoflife_scdadult_up_allnight_past7days)
5. In the past 7 days, how often did you stay up half of the night because you could not fall asleep? (qualityoflife_scdadult_up_halfnight_past7days)
Stiffness Impact (stiffness_820201)
1. In the past 7 days, how often were your joints very stiff when you woke up? (qualityoflife_scdadult_wokeup_stiff_past7days)
2. In the past 7 days, how often were your joints very stiff during the day? (qualityoflife_scdadult_stiff_duringday_past7days)
3. In the past 7 days, how often were your joints so stiff during the day that you could not move? (qualityoflife_scdadult_unablemove_duringday_past7days)
4. In the past 7 days, how often did you wake up so stiff that you could not move? (qualityoflife_scdadult_wakeup_unablemove_past7days)
5. In the past 7 days, how often did it take you a very long time to get out of bed because of stiffness? (qualityoflife_scdadult_time_getoutbed_past7days)
Pain Impact (pain_820201)
1. In the past 7 days, how often did you have pain so bad that you could not do anything for a whole day? (qualityoflife_scdadult_pain_noactivity_past7days)
2. In the past 7 days, how often did you have pain so bad that you could not get out of bed? (qualityoflife_scdadult_unable_outofbed_past7days)
3. In the past 7 days, how often did you have very severe pain? (qualityoflife_scdadult_often_severepain_past7days)
4. In the past 7 days, how often did you have pain so bad that you had to stop what you were doing? (qualityoflife_scdadult_stop_activity_past7days)
5. In the past 7 days, how often did you have pain so bad that it was hard to finish what you were doing? (qualityoflife_scdadult_finish_activity_past7days)
Pain Episodes (pain_episodes_820201)
1. In the past 12 months, how many sickle cell pain attacks (crises) did you have? (qualityoflife_scdadult_painattack_crises_past12months)

validValue.meaningText: I did not have a pain attack (crises) in the past 12 months
validValue.description: I did not have a pain attack (crises) in the past 12 months

question.questionText: 2. When was your last pain attack (crisis)? (qualityoflife_scdadult_last_painattack_crisis)

validValue.meaningText: I've never had a pain attack (crisis)
validValue.description: I've never had a pain attack (crisis)

question.questionText: 3. Using any number from 0 to 10, where 0 is no pain and 10 is the worst pain imaginable, how severe was your pain during your last pain attack (crisis)? (qualityoflife_scdadult_painserverity_duringattack_crisis)

validValue.meaningText: I've never had a pain attack (crisis)
validValue.description: I've never had a pain attack (crisis)

question.questionText: 4. How much did your last pain attack (crisis) interfere with your life? (qualityoflife_scdadult_lastpainattack_crisis_interfere)

validValue.meaningText: I've never had a pain attack (crisis)
validValue.description: I've never had a pain attack (crisis)

validValue.meaningText: Not at all, I did everything I usually do
validValue.description: Not at all, I did everything I usually do

validValue.meaningText: I had to cut down on some things I usually do
validValue.description: I had to cut down on some things I usually do

validValue.meaningText: I could not do most things I usually do
validValue.description: I could not do most things I usually do

validValue.meaningText: I could not take care of myself and needed some help from family or friends
validValue.description: I could not take care of myself and needed some help from family or friends

validValue.meaningText: I could not take care of myself and needed constant care from family, friends, doctors, or nurses
validValue.description: I could not take care of myself and needed constant care from family, friends, doctors, or nurses

question.questionText: 5. About how long did your most recent pain attack (crisis) last? (qualityoflife_scdadult_length_recentpainattack_crisis)

validValue.meaningText: I've never had a pain attack (crisis)
validValue.description: I've never had a pain attack (crisis)

question.questionText: Scoring information is available from Keller S. D., Evensen, C., Yang, M., and Owens, T. (2011). Adult Sickle Cell Quality of Life Measurement Information System user's manual and interpretation guide. Bethesda, MD: U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, National Institutes of Health, National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute. (scoring_820201)

protocol.longName: Adult Sickle Cell Quality of Life Measurement Information System (ASCQ-Me)
protocol.preferredDefinition: This protocol includes 30 self-administered questions from the short form of the Adult Sickle Cell Quality of Life Measurement Information System (ASCQ-Me). Domains covered include emotional impact (5 items), social functioning impact (5 items), sleep impact (5 items), stiffness impact (5 items), pain episode (5 items), and pain frequency (5 items).

form.longName: PhenX PX820401 - Selfefficacy In Sickle Cell Disease
form.preferredDefinition: The Sickle Cell Disease Self-Efficacy Scale is a nine-item self-administered questionnaire that measures disease-specific perceptions of the ability to manage day-to-day issues resulting from sickle cell disease (SCD). Items are scores according to a five-point scale ranging from "1 - Not sure at all" to "5 - Very sure." Responses from individual items are summed to give an overall score with higher scores indicating greater self-efficacy.

headerInstruction.text: Sickle Cell Disease SelfEfficacy Scale: The following questions ask about how sure you are in dealing daytoday with sickle cell disease. There are no right or wrong answers we just want to know what you think. So for each question, tell us ho..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: 1. How sure are you that you can do something to cut down on most of the pain? (selfefficacyscd_sure_something_reduce_pain)
2. How sure are you that you can keep doing most of the things you do daytoday? (selfefficacyscd_sure_doing_daytoday)
3. How sure are you that you can keep sickle cell disease pain from interfering with your sleep? (selfefficacyscd_sure_preventpain_interfering_sleep)
4. How sure are you that you can reduce your sickle cell disease pain by using methods other than taking medications? (selfefficacyscd_sure_reducepain_nonmedication)
5. How sure are you that you can control how often or when you get tired? (selfefficacyscd_sure_control_frequency_gettired)
6. How sure are you that you can do something to help yourself feel better if you are feeling sad or blue? (selfefficacyscd_sure_dosomething_feelbetter)
7. As compared with other people with sickle cell disease, how sure are you that you can manage your life from daytoday? (selfefficacyscd_life_management_daytodayy)
8. How sure are you that you can manage your sickle cell disease symptoms so that you can do the things you enjoy doing? (selfefficacyscd_sure_managediseasesymptoms)
9. How sure are you that you can deal with the frustration of having sickle cell disease? (selfefficacyscd_sure_dealfrustration_havingdisease)
Responses from individual items are summed to give an overall score, with higher scores indicating greater selfefficacy. (scoring_820401)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Sickle Cell Disease Self-Efficacy Scale is a nine-item self-administered questionnaire that measures disease-specific perceptions of the ability to manage day-to-day issues resulting from sickle cell disease (SCD). Items are scores according to a five-point scale ranging from "1 - Not sure at all" to "5 - Very sure." Responses from individual items are summed to give an overall score with higher scores indicating greater self-efficacy.

form.longName: PhenX PX820701 - Stroke Impact Scale Sis Adults
form.preferredDefinition: The Stroke Impact Scale (SIS) includes 59 proxy- or self-report items in 8 domains that assess multidimensional stroke outcomes. Items 1(a-d) measure strength. Items 2(a-g) measure memory and thinking. Items 3(a-I) measure emotions. Items 4(a-g) measure ease or difficulty of communication. Items 5(a-j) measure activities of daily living/instrumental activities of daily living (ADL/IADL). Items 6(a-I) measure mobility. Items 7(a-e) measure hand function. Items 8(a-h) measure participation/role function. Item responses are scored on a 5-point Likert-style scale. A score of 1 = an inability to complete the item and a score of 5 = no difficulty experienced at all. A standardized score ranging from 0 to 100 is calculated for all domains, with higher scores indicating a higher quality of life. An extra question on stroke recovery asks that the client rate on a scale from 0 to 100 how much the client feels that he/she has recovered from his/her stroke, where 0 = "no recovery" and 100 = "full recovery."

headerInstruction.text: Stroke Impact Scale : VERSION 3.0 The purpose of this questionnaire is to evaluate how stroke has impacted your health and life. We want to know from YOUR POINT OF VIEW how stroke has affected you. We will ask you questions about impairments ..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: These questions are about the physical problems which may have occurred as a result of your stroke. (physical_820701)
1a. In the past week, how would you rate the strength of your arm that was most affected by your stroke? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_strength_past7days_arm)
1b. In the past week, how would you rate the strength of your grip of your hand that was most affected by your stroke? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_strength_past7days_grip)
1c. In the past week, how would you rate the strength of your leg that was most affected by your stroke? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_strength_past7days_leg)
1d. In the past week, how would you rate the strength of your foot/ankle that was most affected by your stroke? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_strength_past7days_foot_ankle)
These questions are about your memory and thinking. (memory_820701)
2a. In the past week, how difficult was it for you to remember things that people just told you? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past7days_remember_things)
2b. In the past week, how difficult was it for you to remember things that happened the day before? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past7days_remember_previousday)

2c. In the past week, how difficult was it for you to remember to do things (e.g., keep scheduled appointments or take medication)? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past7days_remember_dothings)
2d. In the past week, how difficult was it for you to remember the day of the week? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past7days_remember_weekday)
2e. In the past week, how difficult was it for you to concentrate? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past7days_concentrate)
2f. In the past week, how difficult was it for you to think quickly? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past7days_think)
2g. In the past week, how difficult was it for you to solve everyday problems? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past7days_problems)
These questions are about how you feel, about changes in your mood and about your ability to control your emotions since your stroke (mood_820701)
3a. In the past week, how often did you feel sad? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_did_past7days_feelsad)
3b. In the past week, how often did you feel that there is nobody you are close to? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_did_past7days_feelnobody_close)
3c. In the past week, how often did you feel that you are a burden to others? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_did_past7days_feelburden_others)
3d. In the past week, how often did you feel that you have nothing to look forward to? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_did_past7days_feelnothing_forward)
3e. In the past week, how often did you blame yourself for mistakes that you made? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_did_past7days_blame_mistakes)
3f. In the past week, how often did you enjoy things as much as ever? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_did_past7days_enjoythings)
3g. In the past week, how often did you feel quite nervous? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_did_past7days_feelnervous)
3h. In the past week, how often did you feel that life is worth living? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_did_past7days_feelworth_living)
3i. In the past week, how often did you smile and laugh at least once a day? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_did_past7days_smile_laugh)
The following questions are about your ability to communicate with other people, as well as your ability to understand what you read and what you hear in a conversation. (conversation_820701)
4a. In the past week, how difficult was it to say the name of someone who was in front of you? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past7days_name_someone)
4b. In the past week, how difficult was it to understand what was being said to you in a conversation? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past7days_understand_conversation)
4c. In the past week, how difficult was it to reply to questions? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past7days_replyto_questions)
4d. In the past week, how difficult was it to correctly name objects? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past7days_name_objects)
4e. In the past week, how difficult was it to participate in a conversation with a group of people? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past7days_participatein_conversation)
4f. In the past week, how difficult was it to have a conversation on the telephone? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past7days_haveconversation_telephone)

4g. In the past week, how difficult was it to call another person on the telephone, including selecting the correct phone number and dialing? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past7days_callperson_telephone)
The following questions ask about activities you might do during a typical day. (typical_day_820701)
5a. In the past 2 weeks, how difficult was it to cut your food with a knife and fork? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past2weeks_cut_food)
5b. In the past 2 weeks, how difficult was it to dress the top part of your body? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past2weeks_dresstop_body)
5c. In the past 2 weeks, how difficult was it to bathe yourself? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past2weeks_bathe_yourself)
5d. In the past 2 weeks, how difficult was it to clip your toenails? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past2weeks_cliptoenails)
5e. In the past 2 weeks, how difficult was it to get to the toilet on time? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past2weeks_toileton_time)
5f. In the past 2 weeks, how difficult was it to control your bladder (not have an accident)? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past2weeks_control_bladder)
5g. In the past 2 weeks, how difficult was it to control your bowels (not have an accident)? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past2weeks_control_bowels)

5h. In the past 2 weeks, how difficult was it to do light household tasks/chores (e.g., dust, make a bed, take out garbage, do the dishes)? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past2weeks_lightchores_tasks)
5i. In the past 2 weeks, how difficult was it to go shopping? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past2weeks_go_shopping)
5j. In the past 2 weeks, how difficult was it to do heavy household chores (e.g., vacuum, laundry or yard work)? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past2weeks_heavy_chores)
The following questions are about your ability to be mobile at home and in the community. (community_820701)
6a. In the past 2 weeks, how difficult was it to stay sitting without losing your balance? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past2weeks_stay_sitting)
6b. In the past 2 weeks, how difficult was it to stay standing without losing your balance? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past2weeks_stay_standing)
6c. In the past 2 weeks, how difficult was it to walk without losing your balance? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past2weeks_walkwithout_losingbalance)
6d. In the past 2 weeks, how difficult was it to move from a bed to a chair? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past2weeks_movebedto_chair)
6e. In the past 2 weeks, how difficult was it to walk one block? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past2weeks_walk_oneblock)
6f. In the past 2 weeks, how difficult was it to walk fast? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past2weeks_walk_fast)
6g. In the past 2 weeks, how difficult was it to climb one flight of stairs? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past2weeks_climb_oneflightstairs)
6h. In the past 2 weeks, how difficult was it to climb several flights of stairs? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past2weeks_climb_severalflightsstairs)
6i. In the past 2 weeks, how difficult was it to get in and out of a car? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_past2weeks_getinout_car)
The following questions are about your ability to use your hand that was MOST AFFECTED by your stroke. (hand_affected_820701)

7a. In the past 2 weeks, how difficult was it to use your hand that was most affected by your stroke to carry heavy objects (e.g., bag of groceries)? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_hand_past2weeks_carryobjects)
7b. In the past 2 weeks, how difficult was it to use your hand that was most affected by your stroke to turn a doorknob? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_hand_past2weeks_turndoorknob)
7c. In the past 2 weeks, how difficult was it to use your hand that was most affected by your stroke to open a can or jar? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_hand_past2weeks_opencanjar)
7d. In the past 2 weeks, how difficult was it to use your hand that was most affected by your stroke to tie a shoe lace? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_hand_past2weeks_tieshoelace)
7e. In the past 2 weeks, how difficult was it to use your hand that was most affected by your stroke to pick up a dime? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_difficult_hand_past2weeks_pickupdime)

The following questions are about how stroke has affected your ability to participate in the activities that you usually do, things that are meaningful to you and help you to find purpose in life. (activities_820701)
8a. During the past 4 weeks, how much of the time have you been limited in your work (paid, voluntary or other)? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_timelimited_past4weeks_work)
8b. During the past 4 weeks, how much of the time have you been limited in your social activities? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_timelimited_past4weeks_social_activities)
8c. During the past 4 weeks, how much of the time have you been limited in quiet recreation (crafts, reading)? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_timelimited_past4weeks_quiet_recreation)
8d. During the past 4 weeks, how much of the time have you been limited in active recreation (sports, outings, travel)? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_timelimited_past4weeks_active_recreation)
8e. During the past 4 weeks, how much of the time have you been limited in your role as a family member and/or friend? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_timelimited_past4weeks_role_familyfriend)

8f. During the past 4 weeks, how much of the time have you been limited in your participation in spiritual or religious activities? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_timelimited_past4weeks_spiritualreligous_activities)
8g. During the past 4 weeks, how much of the time have you been limited in your ability to control your life as you wish? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_timelimited_past4weeks_control_life)
8h. During the past 4 weeks, how much of the time have you been limited in your ability to help others? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_timelimited_past4weeks_help_others)
Stroke Recovery (recovery_820701)

9. On a scale of 0 to 100, with 100 representing full recovery and 0 representing no recovery, how much have you recovered from your stroke? (functionalityafterstrokeadult_representing_stroke_recovery)

Scoring: Each item is rated in a 5point Likert scale in terms of the difficulty the patient has experienced in completing each item. A score of 1 = an inability to complete the item and a score of 5 = no difficulty experienced at all. Summative scores are generated for each domain. Domain scores range from 0100.The Stroke Impact Scale (SIS) is scored in the following way, for each domain:Transformed Scale = [(Actual raw score lowest possible raw score) / Possible raw score range] x 100Three items in the emotion domain, 3f, 3h, and 3i, are reversescored, i.e., 1 becomes 5, 2 becomes 4, 3 remains the same, 4 becomes 2, and 5 becomes 1, prior to manual calculation. For these items, use the following equation to compute the individual's score:6 individual's rating = item scoreThe last item assesses the participant's overall perception of recovery and is presented in the form of a visual analog scale from 0 to 100, where 0 = "no recovery" and 100 = "full recovery." (scoring_820701)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Stroke Impact Scale (SIS) includes 59 proxy- or self-report items in 8 domains that assess multidimensional stroke outcomes. Items 1(a-d) measure strength. Items 2(a-g) measure memory and thinking. Items 3(a-I) measure emotions. Items 4(a-g) measure ease or difficulty of communication. Items 5(a-j) measure activities of daily living/instrumental activities of daily living (ADL/IADL). Items 6(a-I) measure mobility. Items 7(a-e) measure hand function. Items 8(a-h) measure participation/role function. Item responses are scored on a 5-point Likert-style scale. A score of 1 = an inability to complete the item and a score of 5 = no difficulty experienced at all. A standardized score ranging from 0 to 100 is calculated for all domains, with higher scores indicating a higher quality of life. An extra question on stroke recovery asks that the client rate on a scale from 0 to 100 how much the client feels that he/she has recovered from his/her stroke, where 0 = "no recovery" and 100 = "full recovery."

form.longName: PhenX PX820101 - Quality Of Care Adults
form.preferredDefinition: The Adult Sickle Cell Quality of Life Measurement Information System (ASCQ-Me) Quality of Care Module is a set of 27 questions administered to adults with sickle cell disease (SCD) to determine the quality of care that they have received from health care providers.

headerInstruction.text: Adult Sickle Cell Quality of Life Measurement Information System (ASCQMe): Answer all the questions by selecting the best answer to the right of the questions.? You are sometimes told to skip over some questions in this survey. When this happe..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: 1. In the past 12 months, did you try to make an appointment to see a doctor or nurse? (qualityofcareadults_doctor_appointment_past12months)

2. In the past 12 months, when you tried to make an appointment to see a doctor or nurse, how often were you able to get one as soon as you wanted? (qualityofcareadults_frequency_get_appointment_past12months)
3. In the past 12 months, how often were you satisfied with the care you received during these scheduled appointments? (qualityofcareadults_satisfiedcarereceived_appointment_past12months)
4. Do you have a doctor or nurse who you usually see if you need a checkup, want advice about a health problem, or get sick or hurt? (qualityofcareadults_doctornurse_usuallysee)
5. In the past 12 months, how many visits have you had with this doctor or nurse? (qualityofcareadults_visits_doctornurse_usuallysee_past12months)
6. In the past 12 months, how often did this doctor or nurse explain things in a way that is easy to understand? (qualityofcareadults_explainthings_doctornurse_usuallysee_past12months)
7. In the past 12 months, how often did this doctor or nurse listen carefully to you? (qualityofcareadults_listencarefully_doctornurse_usuallysee_past12months)
8. In the past 12 months, how often did this doctor or nurse treat you with courtesy and respect? (qualityofcareadults_courtesyrespect_doctornurse_usuallysee_past12months)
9. In the past 12 months, how often did this doctor or nurse spend enough time with you? (qualityofcareadults_enoughtime_doctornurse_usuallysee_past12months)
10. In the past 12 months, how often were you satisfied with the care you received from this doctor or nurse? (qualityofcareadults_satisfiedcare_doctornurse_usuallysee_past12months)
11. How much does this doctor or nurse know how sickle cell affects you personally? (qualityofcareadults_doctornurse_usuallysee_knowaffects_personally)
12. Does this doctor or nurse treat a lot of patients with sickle cell disease? (qualityofcareadults_doctornurse_usuallysee_treatlot_patients)
13. In the past 12 months, did you go to an emergency room for any sickle cell care you needed right away? (qualityofcareadults_emergencyroom_rightaway_past12months)
14. In the past 12 months, when you went to the emergency room for this care, how often did you get it as soon as you wanted? (qualityofcareadults_emergencyroom_oftencare_soonwanted_past12months)

15. In the past 12 months, when you went to the emergency room for this care, how often did the DOCTORS treating you seem to really care about you? (qualityofcareadults_emergencyroom_oftendoctors_care_past12months)

16. In the past 12 months, when you went to the emergency room for this care, how often did the NURSES treating you seem to really care about you? (qualityofcareadults_emergencyroom_oftennurses_care_past12months)

17. In the past 12 months, when you went to the emergency room for this care, how often did the clerks and receptionists treat you with courtesy and respect? (qualityofcareadults_emergencyroom_clerksreceptionists_courtesyrespect_past12months)

18. In the past 12 months, when you went to the emergency room for this care, how often were you satisfied with the care you received? (qualityofcareadults_emergencyroom_oftensatisfied_care_past12months)
19. In the past 12 months, how many times did you manage a pain attack (crisis) at home without going to a doctor, clinic, or hospital? (qualityofcareadults_painattackcrisis_manage_home_past12months)

validValue.meaningText: I did not have a pain attack (crisis) in the past 12 months (If you did not have a pain attack in the last 12 months, Go to Question 27)
validValue.description: I did not have a pain attack (crisis) in the past 12 months (If you did not have a pain attack in the last 12 months, Go to Question 27)

question.questionText: 20. In the past 12 months, did you ever delay or avoid going to an emergency room when you thought you needed care? (qualityofcareadults_emergencyroom_delayavoidcare_past12months)

validValue.meaningText: Yes, I did not always go for care when I needed it
validValue.description: Yes, I did not always go for care when I needed it

validValue.meaningText: No, I always went for care when I thought I needed it (If No, Go to Question 23)
validValue.description: No, I always went for care when I thought I needed it (If No, Go to Question 23)

question.questionText: 21. How important were bad experiences in the emergency room in your decision to avoid going for care? (qualityofcareadults_bad_experiences_emergencyroom)
22. How important were health insurance issues in your decision to avoid going for care? (qualityofcareadults_health_insurance_avoid_care)
23. In the past 12 months, how many times did you go to the emergency room because of a pain attack (crisis)? (qualityofcareadults_emergencyroom_painattackcrisis_past12months)
24. In the past 12 months, how much were the emergency room doctors and nurses able to help your pain? (qualityofcareadults_emergencyroom_doctorsnurses_helppain_past12months)

25. In the past 12 months, how much did the emergency room doctors and nurses believe that you had very bad sickle cell pain? (qualityofcareadults_emergencyroom_doctorsnurses_believepain_past12months)
26. In the past 12 months, what is the longest you had to wait in the emergency room before your sickle cell pain was treated? (qualityofcareadults_emergencyroom_wait_paintreated_past12months)

validValue.meaningText: More than 1 hour but less than 2 hours
validValue.description: More than 1 hour but less than 2 hours

question.questionText: 27. Using any number from 0 to 10 where 0 is the worst care possible and 10 is the best care possible, what number would you use to rate all of the care you received for your health in the last 12 months? (qualityofcareadults_ratingcare_received_past12months)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Adult Sickle Cell Quality of Life Measurement Information System (ASCQ-Me) Quality of Care Module is a set of 27 questions administered to adults with sickle cell disease (SCD) to determine the quality of care that they have received from health care providers.

form.longName: PhenX PX811301 - Serum Or Plasma Ferritin
form.preferredDefinition: The National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) 2009-2010 Laboratory Procedures Manual for serum/plasma ferritin testing provides comprehensive instructions for processing and storing blood samples to determine an individual's serum ferritin level. Because there are many comparable assays and instruments for measuring ferritin, the protocol also provides basic guidelines to aid comparability among different studies.

headerInstruction.text: The following is a summary version of the full National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey 20112012 protocol.Exclusion Criteria:Persons will be excluded from this component if they: Report that they have hemophilia or Report that they ha..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: Do you have hemophilia? (serumplasmaferritin_hemophilia)
If the SP answers "Yes," the SP is excluded from the blood draw. If SP answers "No" or "Don't Know," blood is drawn from the SP (hemo_811301)
Have you received cancer chemotherapy in the past four weeks or do you anticipate such therapy in the next four weeks? (serumplasmaferritin_chemotheraphy_4weeks)
If the SP answers "Yes," the SP is excluded from the blood draw. If SP answers "No" or "Don't Know," blood is drawn from the SP (chemo_811301)
Ferritin level (serumplasmaferritin_amount)
Repeatability of the ferritin assay (serumplasmaferritin_assay_repeatability)
Record the results of the blood draw. (serumplasmaferritin_blood_draw_results)
Record reasons for a tube not being drawn according to the protocol. (serumplasmaferritin_blood_drawtube_deviation)
Coefficients of variation of the ferritin assay (serumplasmaferritin_coefficients_variation_assay)
Make of the equipment used to perform the ferritin assay (serumplasmaferritin_equipment_make)
Manufacturer of the equipment used to perform the ferritin assay (serumplasmaferritin_equipment_manufacturer)
Gender (serumplasmaferritin_gender)
Record any comments about the venipuncture. (serumplasmaferritin_venipuncture_comments)

Venipuncture Procedures: Editor's Note: Please review chapter 4 of the Laboratory Procedures Manual from the 20112012 National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) for a full description of phlebotomy procedures. This manual is posted here, and is also available at the NHANES website: 20112012 NHANES Laboratory Procedures ManualVenipuncture should generally be performed using the median cubital, cephalic, or basilic veins in the left arm unless this arm is unsuitable. If the veins in the left arm are unsuitable, look for suitable veins on the right arm. If the veins in the antecubital space on both arms are not suitable, then look for veins in the forearm or dorsal side of the hand on the left arm/hand and then the right arm/hand. Fill a 3 or 4 ml K3 EDTA tube with blood. Recording the Results of the Venipuncture Procedure: Immediately after completing the venipuncture, record the results of the blood draw, the reasons for a tube not being drawn according to the protocol, and any comments about the venipuncture. Collection tube should be standardized across the study duration. (venipuncture_811301)

Laboratory Assay for Ferritin: The Sickle Cell Disease Cardiovascular, Pulmonary, and Renal Working Group notes that there are a number of different assays and instruments that are appropriate to measure ferritin. Once an assay is chosen for a particular study, the Working Group recommends that no changes in the protocol be made over the course of the study. To aid comparability, the Working Group recommends that the investigator record the make and manufacturer of equipment used and the repeatability and coefficients of variation for the assay. (lab_assay_811301)

Reference Ranges (Normal Values) for Ferritin: Ferritin reference ranges are assayspecific. The Roche Diagnostics kit used by NHANES specifies expected values of 30400 ng/mL for men and 13150 ng/mL for women. Note: A full description of the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey procedure for serum ferritin testing can be found in the 20092010 Laboratory Procedure Manual posted here, and is also available at the NHANES website: www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/nhanes/nhanes_09_10/FERTIN_F_met_ferritin.pdf. (ranges_811301)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) 2009-2010 Laboratory Procedures Manual for serum/plasma ferritin testing provides comprehensive instructions for processing and storing blood samples to determine an individual's serum ferritin level. Because there are many comparable assays and instruments for measuring ferritin, the protocol also provides basic guidelines to aid comparability among different studies.
